Just met with Vice President Pence and FEMA officials at the White House to discuss the federal response to the Thomas Fire. Our conversations focused on federal support to combat the Thomas Fire and a forthcoming relief aid package to help communities recover once the fire is contained. My statement:

Over the course of the last week, the Thomas Fire has destroyed at least 709 homes on the Central Coast and continues to threaten thousands more. As families’ lives are upended and people are evacuated from their homes, the GOP has put forward a tax plan that eliminates a critical deduction benefiting those who suffered financial losses due to wildfires. I am heartbroken for the families affected by the Thomas Fire and I continue to oppose a plan that cuts taxes for the wealthiest individuals and multinational corporations at the expense of Central Coast families.

I believe that protecting net neutrality is critical because all Americans should have access to a free and open internet. I joined my colleagues urging the Federal Communications Commission to delay their vote on #NetNeutrality.

Grateful to the over 8,000 firefighters from 10 different states fighting the #ThomasFire and have increased containment to 30% today. There have been 41 moments of silence in Congress, but not enough action. Deeply saddened to hear that the Thomas Fire has claimed the life of fire apparatus engineer Cory Iverson from San Diego. His bravery and sacrifice will not be forgotten by our community. My thoughts and prayers are with Cory's unit, his wife, and loved ones.

As hundreds of our California National Guard troops mobilize to help battle one of the largest fires in California’s history, using four UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, it is clear that reliable aircrafts are critical to preparing for future natural disasters. The devastating effects of the Thomas Fire have shown us how critical it is for our local fire departments to have adequate resources to train and prepare for disaster response. Earlier this month, I joined my colleagues urging Congress to reauthorize funding for the Assistance to Firefighters Grants (AFG) and Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response (SAFER) programs. Yesterday, the House passed H.R. 4661, maintaining funding for both of these emergency response and prevention programs for another six years. The proper training and equipment can mean the difference between life and death when it comes to fire safety and prevention and I am glad to Congress has acted to ensure these programs are properly funded.

Thankful for the men and women defending our nation who won’t be home during the holiday season. To our troops serving abroad: Thank you and happy holidays.

The roughly 24,000 acres of undeveloped land at Bixby Ranch, now the Jack and Laura Dangermond Preserve, is some of the most beautiful on the Central Coast. At a time when public land is at risk, I’m happy to see that Bixby Ranch’s pristine beauty will be preserved for generations to come.
Wishing all of the residents of the Central Coast and their families a happy and healthy holiday season. Merry Christmas everyone!

While many of us celebrate the holidays at home with our families, let us not forget the service members spending their Christmas abroad serving our nation. I was fortunate enough to spend this Christmas with some of our bravest troops deployed in Iraq from California and across the country. Happy holidays and thank you for your sacrifice.
I'll be spending this week with a bipartisan delegation in Iraq and Afganistan to learn about the challenges and experiences of our troops stationed in the Middle East.

Yesterday, I met with the impressive Coalition stationed at Q-West outside Baghdad. These Troopers have liberated over 105,500 square kilometers from ISIS control across Iraq and Syria and helped stabilize life for 7.5 million civilians. It was an honor to meet you all.

Had a great breakfast with service men and women on the USS Theodore Roosevelt aircraft carrier in Dubai, where I learned first-hand about their capabilities, challenges, and readiness. In Abu Dhabi I received information about the partnership between the US and the United Arab Emirates and the joint activities in the region.

Rode a helicopter into Afghanistan yesterday to visit service members, many of which are from California, at the Bagram Airfield (BAF). Learning about our ongoing challenges and the dynamic relationships between nations in the region has been an incredible experience. I’m amazed by our military intelligence community and the technology and strategies they employ.

Last stop: A visit with Marines in Bastion, Afghanistan. Many of the service members I met with this week were from the Central Coast, including CPL Flores to my left who is from Fillmore! I’m thankful to have been a part of this delegation and gain such first-hand knowledge that will assist me in my work on the House Armed Services Committee. Wishing a happy new year to all of our deployed service men and women.
